Neuperlach is located east of the boroughs Ramersdorf and Perlach, south of the city districts no. 14 (Berg am Laim) and no. 15 (Trudering-Riem), west of the borough Waldperlach and north of Unterbiberg (which is part of the municipality of Neubiberg).  The borough encompasses multiplehousing estates, including several high-rise estates, and is one of Germany's biggest satellite towns.  In the center of Neuperlach the large pep shopping mall is located, one of the most profitable shopping centers in Germany.  The Hachinger Bach runs through the western part of Neuperlach from north to south.  The stream also passes through the western part of the Ostpark.

context: [PAR] [TLE] Heisman curse [SEP] The Heisman curse is a term coined to reference a two-part assertion of a negative future for the winning player of the Heisman Trophy.  The "curse" supposes that any college football player who wins the Heisman plays on a team that will likely lose its subsequent bowl game.  The trend of post-award failure has garnered the attention of the mainstream media.  Talk of a curse in relation to bowl results was particularly prevalent from 2003 to 2008, when six Heisman Trophy winners compiled a cumulative 1–5 bowl game record, and five of those six led number one ranked teams into the Bowl Championship Series (BCS) National Championship Game as favorites (Heisman Trophy winners, including Reggie Bush, who gave back his Heisman Trophy, are 4–8 overall in the BCS National Championship Game and College Football Playoff National Championship, although prior to 2009 they were 1–6).  Additionally, the Heisman curse asserts that in most cases a Heisman winner will have either a poor career in the National Football League (NFL), or in fact not even see such a football career at all.  Although many Heisman winners have not enjoyed success at the professional level, including players like Matt Leinart, Andre Ware, Jason White, Rashaan Salaam, Eric Crouch, Ty Detmer, Troy Smith and Gino Torretta, proponents of the "curse" rarely cite highly successful players such as Barry Sanders, Charles Woodson, Eddie George, Tim Brown, Bo Jackson, Marcus Allen, Earl Campbell, and Tony Dorsett among the notables. [PAR] [TLE] Jason White (American football) [SEP] Jason White (born June 19, 1980) is an American former college football quarterback who played for the University of Oklahoma, was recognized as a unanimous All-American, and won the Heisman Trophy in 2003.  White is currently a business owner in Oklahoma.
topic: The criteria used to define "success" or "failure" for Heisman Trophy winners transitioning to the NFL.
response:
<document_analysis>
1. **Thoughtful Content Examination**: The provided text discusses the "Heisman curse," a perceived trend of Heisman Trophy winners experiencing negative outcomes in subsequent bowl games and/or failing to achieve success in the NFL. It highlights both players who seemingly validate the curse (Leinart, Ware, etc.) and those who defy it (Sanders, Woodson, etc.). The text also provides a specific example, Jason White, a Heisman winner who is now a business owner.
2. **Concept Exploration**: The concept of a "curse" is inherently statistical. The text implicitly acknowledges this by discussing win-loss records. The question should explore the validity of attributing failure to a "curse" versus other factors influencing player success (e.g., team quality, player skill, injury, position). The contrast between successful and unsuccessful Heisman winners is central to understanding the debate.
3. **Strategic Complexity Calibration**: Difficulty: 9/10. This is a challenging topic because it requires understanding statistical probability, the complexities of NFL success, and the psychological aspect of a self-fulfilling prophecy (the "curse" itself). The question needs to go beyond simple recall and require analytical thinking.
4. **Intentional Question Planning**: The question will focus on the multifaceted nature of evaluating a Heisman winner’s success in the NFL, prompting consideration of factors beyond individual performance and acknowledging the statistical nature of the "curse." It will require the domain expert to weigh various metrics and potential biases.
</document_analysis>

<output_format>
Question: Considering the historical performance of Heisman Trophy winners transitioning to the NFL, which of the following best encapsulates the primary challenge in definitively assessing the validity of the “Heisman Curse”?
A: The limited sample size of Heisman Trophy winners compared to the overall NFL player pool makes statistically significant conclusions unreliable.
B: The inherent subjectivity in defining “success” in the NFL, encompassing factors beyond traditional statistics like wins and awards.
C: The tendency of media outlets to disproportionately highlight failures of Heisman winners while overlooking their successes, creating a biased narrative.
D: The influence of the college football system on player development, often resulting in skills that do not translate effectively to the professional level.
Explanation: The text highlights both successes and failures among Heisman winners, demonstrating that the idea of a “curse” is not universally applicable. Defining success in the NFL is complex, as it’s not solely based on statistics; team dynamics, coaching, and luck all play a role. The text points out that successful players are often overlooked when discussing the curse. Therefore, the subjectivity of defining success is the primary challenge.
Correct Answer: B
</output_format>

context: [PAR] [TLE] Heisman curse [SEP] The Heisman curse is a term coined to reference a two-part assertion of a negative future for the winning player of the Heisman Trophy.  The "curse" supposes that any college football player who wins the Heisman plays on a team that will likely lose its subsequent bowl game.  The trend of post-award failure has garnered the attention of the mainstream media.  Talk of a curse in relation to bowl results was particularly prevalent from 2003 to 2008, when six Heisman Trophy winners compiled a cumulative 1–5 bowl game record, and five of those six led number one ranked teams into the Bowl Championship Series (BCS) National Championship Game as favorites (Heisman Trophy winners, including Reggie Bush, who gave back his Heisman Trophy, are 4–8 overall in the BCS National Championship Game and College Football Playoff National Championship, although prior to 2009 they were 1–6).  Additionally, the Heisman curse asserts that in most cases a Heisman winner will have either a poor career in the National Football League (NFL), or in fact not even see such a football career at all.  Although many Heisman winners have not enjoyed success at the professional level, including players like Matt Leinart, Andre Ware, Jason White, Rashaan Salaam, Eric Crouch, Ty Detmer, Troy Smith and Gino Torretta, proponents of the "curse" rarely cite highly successful players such as Barry Sanders, Charles Woodson, Eddie George, Tim Brown, Bo Jackson, Marcus Allen, Earl Campbell, and Tony Dorsett among the notables. context: [PAR] [TLE] Music for Electric Metronomes [SEP] Music for Electric Metronomes is an avant-garde aleatoric composition written in 1960 by Japanese composer Toshi Ichiyanagi for any number of performers between three and eight.  The piece involves the manipulation of electric metronomes, followed by various unspecified sounds and actions.  It is a very theatrical piece, and reflects Ichiyanagi's affiliation with Fluxus, an experimental art movement from the sixties.  The only true scored "instrument" is an electric metronome for each individual player, though the varying sounds and/or actions may involve many different instruments and objects at the discretion of the performer.  Because the graphic notation of score (which is a series of dashes, lines, and numbers in an erratic pattern of connected paths) leaves a lot of room for personal interpretation and expression, each performance is unique, and almost certainly cannot be reproduced.  There is no conductor for the performance.  It has been recorded on the album "Toshi Ichiyanagi: 1960's & 1990's".  In a review of a performance by the S.E.M. Ensemble in 1992 at the Paula Cooper Gallery, the music critic of "The New York Times", Alex Ross, described the piece as "merely a timid, spastic prelude to György Ligeti's monumental "Poème symphonique" for 100 metronomes". [PAR] [TLE] Toshi Ichiyanagi [SEP] Toshi Ichiyanagi (一柳 慧 , Ichiyanagi Toshi , born 4 February 1933) is a Japanese composer of avant-garde music.  He studied with Tomojiro Ikenouchi, Kishio Hirao, and John Cage.
topic: Compare and contrast the role of the performer in "Music for Electric Metronomes" with traditional ensemble performances.

The text also briefly introduces the composer, Toshi Ichiyanagi.

The reference to Ligeti’s work provides a point of comparison regarding mechanical sound sources.

Intentional Question Planning: The question aims to probe the expert's understanding of how the performer's role is fundamentally altered in this piece compared to traditional ensemble settings.
